subject: Ethics
title: Non-Maleficence in Practice
description: A fast breakdown of Non-Maleficence in Practice for builders.

hook.text: Chemotherapy poisons your body to kill cancer. The treatment that saves you also makes you violently ill.

buildup.text: 'First, do no harm' is medicine's most famous rule. But almost every treatment causes some harm.

discovery.text: Non-maleficence doesn't ban all harm. It requires that the benefit must outweigh the damage caused.

twist.text: Surgeons cut you open to heal you. The principle isn't 'never harm' but 'never harm without good reason.'

climax.text: The hardest cases arise when treatment helps a little but hurts a lot‚Äîand no one can predict which it'll be.

punchline.text: No harm? Impossible. Less harm? That's the real oath.

quiz.question: What does non-maleficence actually require in medical practice?
options: The benefit of treatment must outweigh the harm it causes
Doctors must never cause any pain or discomfort to patients
All surgical procedures are inherently unethical
